items.title: Expert-Grounded Automatic Prompt Engineering for Extracting Lattice Constants of High-Entropy Alloys from Scientific Publications using Large Language Models
items.authors: Shunshun Liu, Talon R. Booth, Yangfeng Ji, Wesley Reinhart, Prasanna V. Balachandran
items.institution: University of Virginia, Pennsylvania State University
items.contributions: 1. Proposes an expert-grounded automatic prompt optimization framework to enhance the reliability of LLMs for entity extraction from scientific publications. 2. Demonstrates the framework's effectiveness on extracting lattice constants of high-entropy alloys, achieving a recall improvement from 0.27 to >0.9 using a small expert-annotated dataset. 3. Shows the optimized prompt's transferability to newer LLMs and identifies key error categories, establishing a low-cost, scalable methodology for scientific data extraction.
items.summary: This paper addresses the challenge of manually refining prompts for using LLMs to extract scientific data from publications. It proposes an automatic prompt optimization framework grounded in expert feedback, which significantly improved recall for extracting lattice constants of high-entropy alloys. The optimized prompt proved effective and transferable, establishing a scalable, low-cost methodology for reliable scientific data extraction with LLMs.
items.mindmap:
graph TB Root[”Expert-Grounded Automatic Prompt Engineering

提示可迁移至新模型”]

items.title: Men and Women Survivors in Science: A Comprehensive Analysis
items.institution: Adam Mickiewicz University
items.contributions: 1. Conducted a large-scale, longitudinal analysis of gender disparities among "survivor" scientists (those who published consistently from 2000 to 2020-2023) across 38 OECD countries. 2. Quantified a persistent gender productivity gap (men 23% more productive cumulatively) while finding no gaps in international collaboration, journal prestige, citations, or team size. 3. Revealed interesting disciplinary differences in gender disparities and high rates of consistent annual publication among survivors in STEMM (80%) and social sciences (70%).
items.summary: This paper analyzes gender disparities among scientists who consistently published from 2000 to 2023 using a large Scopus dataset. It finds a persistent gender productivity gap but no gaps in collaboration, journal selection, citations, or team formation. The study concludes that while men are more productive, male and female "survivors" publish in equally prestigious journals, receive equal citations, and work in teams of equal size.
items.mindmap:

        Method --> M1(”纵向研究 (2000-2023)/Longitudinal Study”)

        Results --> R3(”学科间存在差异/Disciplinary Differences Exist”)

items.title: International Research Collaboration Among Top Performers: A Gender Gap Persists
items.institution: Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan University of Economics and Business
items.contributions: 1. Conducted a large-scale longitudinal study on gender differences in international research collaboration among Polish top-performing STEMM scientists over 30 years (1992-2021). 2. Employed a fractional logistic regression model with fixed effects to quantify the persistent gender gap, finding an 11% higher probability of international collaboration for male top performers. 3. Identified that the gender gap in international collaboration has widened over time and is particularly pronounced in specific disciplines (AGRI, BIO, ENVI, MED).
items.summary: This paper studies the gender gap in international research collaboration among top-performing Polish STEMM scientists over five periods from 1992 to 2021, using Scopus co-authorship data and a fractional logistic regression model. The analysis reveals a persistent and widening gender gap, with male top performers having an approximately 11% higher probability of international collaboration than their female counterparts.
items.mindmap:
graph TB

items.title: Pre-review to Peer review: Pitfalls of Automating Reviews using Large Language Models
items.authors: Akhil Pandey Akella, Harish Varma Siravuri, Shaurya Rohatgi
items.institution: AllSci Corp, Sunwater Capital, Kellogg School of Management (Northwestern University), Northern Illinois University, MBZUAI
items.contributions: 1. Conducted a systematic evaluation of frontier open-weight LLMs for generating peer reviews, measuring alignment with human reviewers and correlation with post-publication metrics like citations and novelty. 2. Identified key pitfalls of LLMs as autonomous reviewers, including weak correlation with human scores (0.15), systematic overestimation bias (3-5 points), and uniformly high confidence scores despite errors. 3. Demonstrated the potential utility of LLMs as pre-review screening agents, as their generated reviews correlate more strongly with post-publication outcomes than with human reviewer scores, and released an open-source dataset (DLMRSD) to support further safety research.
items.summary: This paper evaluates the use of large language models (LLMs) for automating academic peer review by comparing LLM-generated reviews against human reviewer scores and post-publication metrics. The study finds that while LLMs show weak alignment with human reviewers and exhibit overconfidence and bias, their reviews correlate better with future citation impact, suggesting they could serve as useful pre-review screening tools rather than fully autonomous reviewers.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        A[Pre-review to Peer Review: Pitfalls of Automating Reviews using Large Language Models] --> B(核心问题/Problem)
        A --> C(主要方法/Method)
        A --> D(关键结果/Results)
        B --> B1[LLMs用于自动化同行评审的安全性与可靠性/Safety & Reliability of Automating Peer Review with LLMs]
        C --> C1[使用前沿开源LLMs生成评审并与人类评分及发表后指标对比/Using Frontier Open-Weight LLMs to Generate Reviews vs. Human Scores & Post-Publication Metrics]
        D --> D1[LLMs与人类评审员弱相关，存在高估偏差与过度自信/Weak Correlation with Humans, Overestimation Bias, High Confidence]
        D --> D2[LLM评审与发表后指标相关性更强，适合预审筛查/LLM Reviews Correlate More with Post-Publication Metrics, Suitable for Pre-Review Screening]

items.title: Artificial Intelligence Applications in Lean Startup Methodology: A Bibliometric Analysis of Research Trends and Future Directions
items.authors: Parisa Omidmand, Rasam Dorri, Alireza Mozaffari, Saeid Ataei
items.institution: Texas Tech University, University of California, Riverside, Fordham University, Stevens Institute of Technology
items.contributions: 1. Conducted a systematic bibliometric analysis of the intersection between AI and Lean Startup methodology, identifying three distinct research clusters. 2. Revealed the field's characteristics, including fragmented authorship, limited international collaboration, and geographic concentration in developed economies. 3. Identified significant research gaps in ethics, cross-cultural validation, and empirical testing, providing a roadmap for future research.
items.summary: This paper performs a bibliometric analysis of research at the intersection of Artificial Intelligence and Lean Startup methodology. Using the PRISMA framework and VOSviewer software on 12 Scopus articles, it maps the research landscape, identifies key themes and gaps. The study concludes the field is emerging but fragmented, requiring more theoretical consolidation and empirical work to mature.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        A[Artificial Intelligence Applications in Lean Startup Methodology: A Bibliometric Analysis] --> B
        A --> C
        A --> D
        B[核心问题/Problem: 研究AI与精益创业方法论的交叉领域现状与趋势]
        C[主要方法/Method: 使用PRISMA框架和VOSviewer进行文献计量分析]
        D[关键结果/Results: 识别三个研究集群、领域特征及未来研究空白]

items.title: Oignon: Citation Graph Tool
items.institution: Institute for Atmospheric and Environmental Research, University of Wuppertal
items.contributions: 1. A free, open-source tool that removes barriers like mandatory accounts and freemium gating. 2. A dual-path ranking system with recency weighting to capture both foundational and recent works. 3. Addresses scalability and readability issues of traditional force-directed graph layouts.
items.summary: The paper presents Oignon, a free, open-source tool for exploring academic citation graphs. It introduces a dual-path ranking system with recency weighting to systematically visualize both foundational and recent research. The tool aims to overcome common drawbacks like poor scaling, shallow traversal, and access barriers found in existing solutions.

items.title: IANEC: Digital Forensic Investigation of Contemporary Writers' Archives
items.institution: Université Caen Normandie, ENSICAEN, CNRS, Normandie Univ, GREYC UMR 6072
items.contributions: 1. Development of a method to separate system/application files from user files using fingerprint databases for archival analysis, 2. Creation of tools for reading files on Mac partitions and virtualizing operating systems to emulate original computing environments, 3. Implementation of semantic analysis techniques for automatic text classification, image analysis, and detection of sensitive content (e.g., hate speech) in digital archives.
items.summary: The IANEC project develops digital forensic tools to automate the analysis of born-digital archives from contemporary writers. The proposed method combines technical file system analysis (e.g., fingerprinting, virtualization) with semantic document analysis (e.g., text/image classification). The main conclusion is that these tools are essential for the effective extraction, processing, and description of native digital archival corpora in cultural heritage institutions.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        Root[”IANEC: Digital Forensic Investigation of Contemporary Writers' Archives”] --> Problem[”核心问题/Problem: Born-digital archives are prevalent but difficult to analyze manually.”]
        Root --> Method[”主要方法/Method: Develop digital forensic tools for technical and semantic analysis of archives.”]
        Root --> Results[”关键结果/Results: Automated tools are essential for processing and describing digital archival corpora.”]

items.title: Interpretable Link Prediction in AI-Driven Cancer Research: Uncovering Co-Authorship Patterns
items.authors: Shahab Mosallaie, Andrea Schiffauerova, Ashkan Ebadi
items.institution: Concordia University, National Research Council Canada
items.contributions: 1. Constructed 36 overlapping co-authorship networks from 7,738 publications to model new, persistent, and discontinued collaborations in AI-driven cancer research. 2. Engineered both attribute-based and structure-based features and built four machine learning classifiers, with Random Forest achieving the highest recall for all collaboration types. 3. Applied SHAP for model interpretability, identifying key factors like discipline similarity, productivity, and seniority that influence collaboration patterns.
items.summary: This paper uses machine learning to predict collaboration patterns in AI-driven cancer research by analyzing co-authorship networks. The authors built classifiers using engineered features and applied SHAP for interpretability, finding that discipline similarity promotes new and persistent collaborations while high productivity and seniority are linked to discontinued links. The results aim to guide the formation of effective interdisciplinary research teams and inform policy.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        A[Interpretable Link Prediction in AI-Driven Cancer Research: Uncovering Co-Authorship Patterns] --> B[核心问题/Problem]
        A --> C[主要方法/Method]
        A --> D[关键结果/Results]
        B --> B1[挑战: 组建有效的跨学科癌症研究团队/Challenge: Forming effective interdisciplinary cancer research teams]
        C --> C1[构建合著网络作为合作代理/Construct co-authorship networks as collaboration proxy]
        C --> C2[使用机器学习分类器进行链接预测/Use ML classifiers for link prediction]
        C --> C3[使用SHAP进行模型可解释性/Use SHAP for model interpretability]
        D --> D1[随机森林在所有合作类型中召回率最高/Random forest achieved highest recall]
        D --> D2[学科相似性得分是关键因素/Discipline similarity score is a crucial factor]
        D --> D3[高生产力和资历与中断链接正相关/High productivity and seniority positively associated with discontinued links]

items.title: AETAS: Analysis of Evolving Temporal Affect and Semantics for Legal History
items.institution: PingCAP, Data & AI-Innovation Lab
items.contributions: 1. A reproducible, expert-system style pipeline for quantifying and visualizing lexical drift in historical corpora. 2. A method coupling interpretable semantic trajectories with legally meaningful axes (e.g., mercy-versus-retribution). 3. The application of the pipeline to the Old Bailey Corpus, exposing the evolution of legal concepts like justice and crime alongside historical events.
items.summary: This paper presents a reproducible pipeline for analyzing semantic drift in historical legal texts. The method involves training and aligning diachronic word embeddings to quantify and visualize lexical change. The analysis of the Old Bailey Corpus reveals how concepts of justice and crime evolved with penal reforms and societal debates.

items.title: Periodical embeddings uncover hidden interdisciplinary patterns in the subject classification scheme of science
items.institution: City University of Hong Kong
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel quantitative framework that uses classification tasks to evaluate the effectiveness of journal classification schemes. 2. Introduces Periodical2Vec (P2V), a periodical embedding method learned from paper-level citations, which outperforms existing schemes. 3. Uncovers structural patterns in the map of science, such as the reorganization of disciplinary boundaries and the identification of coherent interdisciplinary clusters.
items.summary: The paper addresses the limitations of traditional subject classification schemes by proposing a data-driven framework using Periodical2Vec embeddings derived from citation networks. It demonstrates that this method yields more accurate journal classifications than expert-curated systems like Scopus and reveals a more nuanced, interdisciplinary map of science.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        A[Periodical embeddings uncover hidden interdisciplinary patterns] --> B[核心问题/Problem: Traditional classification schemes are coarse and subjective.]
        A --> C[主要方法/Method: Use Periodical2Vec embeddings from citations and k-means clustering.]
        A --> D[关键结果/Results: Better classification performance and reveals new interdisciplinary clusters.]

items.title: An Automated Grey Literature Extraction Tool for Software Engineering
items.authors: Houcine Abdelkader Cherief, Brahim Mahmoudi, Zacharie Chenail-Larcher, Naouel Moha, Quentin Sti'evenart, Florent Avellaneda
items.institution: École de technologie supérieure, Université du Québec à Montréal
items.contributions: 1. The GLiSE tool, a prompt-driven system for automated grey literature extraction from heterogeneous web sources. 2. A curated dataset of software engineering grey-literature search results classified by semantic relevance. 3. An empirical study evaluating the usability of the proposed tool.
items.summary: The paper addresses the difficulty of collecting and assessing grey literature in software engineering at scale due to heterogeneous sources and formats. It proposes GLiSE, a prompt-driven tool that generates platform-specific queries, gathers results from sources like GitHub and Stack Overflow, and uses embedding-based semantic classifiers to filter and rank results for relevance. The tool is designed for reproducibility and its usability is empirically evaluated.
items.mindmap:
graph TB
        A[An Automated Grey Literature Extraction Tool for Software Engineering] --> B[核心问题/Problem: 收集和评估软件工程灰文献困难/Difficulty in collecting and assessing software engineering grey literature at scale]
        A --> C[主要方法/Method: GLiSE工具, 提示驱动, 嵌入语义分类器/GLiSE tool, prompt-driven, embedding-based semantic classifier]
        A --> D[关键结果/Results: 提供工具、数据集和可用性研究/Provides tool, curated dataset, and usability study]

items.title: The Effect of Gender Diversity on Scientific Team Impact: A Team Roles Perspective
items.authors: Yi Zhao, Yongjun Zhu, Donghun Kim, Yuzhuo Wang, Heng Zhang, Chao Lu, Chengzhi Zhang
items.institution: Anhui University, Yonsei University, Nanjing University, Central China Normal University, Hohai University, Nanjing University of Science and Technology
items.contributions: 1. Introduced a team roles perspective by classifying authors into leadership and support roles using contribution statements, moving beyond aggregate diversity measures. 2. Discovered a non-linear (inverted U-shape) relationship between gender diversity and team impact for both leadership and support groups. 3. Revealed the moderating effect of team size, showing that the impact of leadership-group gender diversity shifts from negative to positive as team size increases, while support-group diversity remains consistently positive.
items.summary: This study investigates how gender diversity within specific team roles (leadership vs. support) affects scientific team impact, measured by citations. By analyzing over 130,000 PLOS papers and using contribution statements to define roles, the authors employed multivariable and threshold regression. They found the relationship is an inverted U-shape, identified high-impact team compositions, and showed that team size significantly moderates the effect of leadership diversity.
items.mindmap:

性别多样性对科研团队影响力的影响] --> B A --> C A --> D B[核心问题/Problem

lack of role-differentiated analysis.

statements for role classification (leadership/support),

1. Inverted U-shape relationship.
2. All-female leadership + all-male support yields high impact.
3. Team size moderates leadership diversity effect.

items.title: Beyond Content: How Author Network Centrality Drives Citation Disparities in Top AI Conferences
items.authors: Renlong Jie, Longfeng Zhao, Chen Chu, Danyang Jia, Zhen Wang
items.institution: Northwestern Polytechnical University, Yunnan University of Finance and Economics
items.contributions: 1. Proposed a novel centrality metric (Harmonic Closeness with Temporal and Collaboration Count Decay - HCTCD) that incorporates temporal decay and collaboration intensity. 2. Advanced the methodological field by employing beta regression to model citation percentiles, appropriately handling the bounded nature of citation data. 3. Demonstrated that team-level centrality aggregation, particularly through exponentially weighted summation, explains citation variance more effectively than individual or rank-based approaches, highlighting the importance of collective network connectivity.
items.summary: This study investigates how authors' positions in scientific collaboration networks influence citation disparities in top AI conferences. It proposes a new centrality metric (HCTCD) and uses beta regression to analyze data from NeurIPS, ICML, and ICLR. The findings show that long-term network centrality, especially at the team level, is a strong predictor of citations, challenging evaluation paradigms that focus solely on content.
items.mindmap:

items.title: Intelligent Knowledge Mining Framework: Bridging AI Analysis and Trustworthy Preservation
items.institution: FernUniversität in Hagen
items.summary: The paper proposes the Intelligent Knowledge Mining Framework (IKMF), a conceptual dual-stream architecture that combines a horizontal AI-driven mining process with a parallel trustworthy archiving stream. It aims to bridge the gap between dynamic analysis and long-term preservation, transforming static data repositories into living, actionable knowledge ecosystems.
